channel.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
channel.description:
I've been intending to learn Lisp for some time, but I'd like some feedback for those who have gotten their feet more than just wet.
Which dialect do you prefer? Common Lisp versus Clojure, I suppose. Any other dialects you prefer? What sort of references got you started learning Lisp? Why did you choose it?
Any other information you'd like to tell me? I have my own reasons for wanting to learn it and they have extensive applications. I might discuss this in greater detail when I start incorporating it, but I wanted to get some feedback for it first.
Thanks.

item.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:22, topic:535115”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=653919.msg4382228#msg4382228 date=1383952747]

Just wondering… what is so special / great about Lisp?

There is nothing special about lisp, just like there is nothing special about every programming language other than the superior C++. However, the usage of and interest in lisp is recognized as a symptom to diagnose hipsterism.

That would be your perception. Lisp is the second oldest language still used today. All the excitement you see these days about Lisp is around the same relative amount of excitement for Lisp last year, and the year before, and a decade ago, and two decades ago, and so on. It turns out a small part of the programming population that find out about Lisp are always excited to learn about it. This trend shall continue forever, because Lisp solves problems in a way other programming languages can’t.

Holy shit, you’re a fgt.

A completely irrelevant (and wrong) comment on my sexuality. Good job for yet another cliche, ad-hominem response.

dont feed the troll???
[/quote]

When I have time I’m gonna get ban powers back to ban him, then go back to talking about useful things. I’m just sick of seeing shit like this.[/quote]

Please stay on topic. You can write about your so-wanted ban powers in the ‘New year’s resolution’ topic when the time comes.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:14, topic:535115”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=653919.msg4382011#msg4382011 date=1383866448]

Just wondering… what is so special / great about Lisp?

There is nothing special about lisp, just like there is nothing special about every programming language other than the superior C++. However, the usage of and interest in lisp is recognized as a symptom to diagnose hipsterism.

That would be your perception. Lisp is the second oldest language still used today. All the excitement you see these days about Lisp is around the same relative amount of excitement for Lisp last year, and the year before, and a decade ago, and two decades ago, and so on. It turns out a small part of the programming population that find out about Lisp are always excited to learn about it. This trend shall continue forever, because Lisp solves problems in a way other programming languages can’t.
[/quote]

Holy shit, you’re a fgt.[/quote]

A completely irrelevant (and wrong) comment on my sexuality. Good job for yet another cliche, ad-hominem response.

RiiPiiNFtW:

It definitely looks like an interesting language to learn, but the syntax of it would dive me crazy just like python does to me already.

New syntax is always a bit deterring for any language, especially if you get caught into learning a C-style language and then learning other C-style languages, then want to learn something radically different. Good for you to learn python, though. It’s a great language and definitely worth learning.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

honestly, who isn’t annoyed by lisp’s excessive parenthesis at first? they are really ugly and hard to read, but like most beginner programmers, you get used to it and it looks nice and elegant.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:15, topic:535115”]It definitely looks like an interesting language to learn, but the syntax of it would dive me crazy just like python does to me already.[/quote]I wouldn’t see why Python syntax “drives you crazy”. It just enforces spacing you should be using anyway, and there are plugins for most editors that show you what block level you’re on as well (if you need them).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:

RiiPiiNFtW:

It definitely looks like an interesting language to learn, but the syntax of it would dive me crazy just like python does to me already.

Not if you use a decent editor that highlights and colorizes your parentheses for you.

item.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:1, topic:535115”]I’ve been intending to learn Lisp for some time, but I’d like some feedback for those who have gotten their feet more than just wet.

Which dialect do you prefer? Common Lisp versus Clojure, I suppose. Any other dialects you prefer? What sort of references got you started learning Lisp? Why did you choose it?

Any other information you’d like to tell me? I have my own reasons for wanting to learn it and they have extensive applications. I might discuss this in greater detail when I start incorporating it, but I wanted to get some feedback for it first.

Thanks.[/quote]
i prefer scheme. it’s simple. go with something like racket or chicken for a nice introduction. open up the common lisp if you actually have big plans and are comfortable with lispiness in general. if you want an embeddable language, scheme is great…

[quote=“Whackatre, post:2, topic:535115”]

i wouldn’t dare to call myself proficient, but anyway, here are my opinions on the dialects i’ve used, subjective or not:

cl: a pretty big and bulky language, and probably considered more ugly (the macros especially) by schemers. nevertheless, it’s quite powerful and there are great implementations (clisp and sbcl are the most common ones, and they’re both great). think the ‘C++ of the lisps’. a good read is Practical Common Lisp.

scheme: elegant; clean. it’s a lot more pure, because it was historically designed as a teaching language. like cl, there are tons of impls (chicken, gambit, etc. etc.), and you’ll spend a lot of time choosing one. racket, a scheme dialect that has deviated from scheme, has tons of great libs and is both a great teaching language and ‘real-world’ language. it’s pretty awesome. anyway, sicp is the definitive book for scheme. an alternate and unorthodox learning approach is the little schemer.

clojure: if you want a lisp that runs on the jvm and has all the familiar java std lib features, use clojure.

i usually use racket. regardless of whether your main goal is education or getting things done, all are applicable for the task.

also, you should check out paul graham’s links. visit #lisp on freenode. the people are pretty nice to talk to there and will help you out with matters even not related to cl.

i’m going to stop talking now because i don’t want to step on s1gma’s feet too much…[/quote]
good post pls post more

catthoor:

Just wondering… what is so special / great about Lisp?

your limit is not the language you use, but your mental stability

Read full topic

item.description:

I am far from proficient, and since I’ve not done any lisp for a long long time, a lot of it is not in my memory. I personally started off with chicken scheme and the holy grail of lisp programming books: SICP.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone proficient with Lisp
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

i wouldn’t dare to call myself proficient, but anyway, here are my opinions on the dialects i’ve used, subjective or not:

cl: a pretty big and bulky language, and probably considered more ugly (the macros especially) by schemers. nevertheless, it’s quite powerful and there are great implementations (clisp and sbcl are the most common ones, and they’re both great). think the ‘C++ of the lisps’. a good read is Practical Common Lisp.

scheme: elegant; clean. it’s a lot more pure, because it was historically designed as a teaching language. like cl, there are tons of impls (chicken, gambit, etc. etc.), and you’ll spend a lot of time choosing one. racket, a scheme dialect that has deviated from scheme, has tons of great libs and is both a great teaching language and ‘real-world’ language. it’s pretty awesome. anyway, sicp is the definitive book for scheme. an alternate and unorthodox learning approach is the little schemer.

clojure: if you want a lisp that runs on the jvm and has all the familiar java std lib features, use clojure.

i usually use racket. regardless of whether your main goal is education or getting things done, all are applicable for the task.

also, you should check out paul graham’s links. visit #lisp on freenode. the people are pretty nice to talk to there and will help you out with matters even not related to cl.

i’m going to stop talking now because i don’t want to step on s1gma’s feet too much…

Read full topic
